author: newfareman
body: I figured the flaw in my logic, but thank you for taking the time to explain. To expand upon it a bit further, I'm trying to fully understand the correlation between the average p/e and the current stock price. I understand there are three different factors to consider which are past, current, and future growth. If you look at Apple and Microsoft they are way above what their average p/e should be. Why would there be such huge percentile increases in these companies? Are people betting on the continued explosive growth of Microsoft with Azure and Apple with their new microchip and new phones coming out? Or is it really hard to say and it's mostly arbitrary? I'm curious to see what your opinion on it is.

author: Trumpowell
body: Billy gates ain't putting a microchip in me

author: Carnivore_kitteh
body:
Google KNOS advfn and search investor hub for some solid DD

It is an air purifier company with tech beyond what any other company has. The owner and inventor has patent after patent on the technology used in the product. He worked for nasa or something... But it doesn't use hepa filters, and instead neutralizes the air of pathogens, bacteria, pollen, and pollution by reading it and adjusting to what is needed. Its filter can be washed in the dishwasher and reused. It also filters 100x smaller particles than hepa. Way cheaper, and easily convertible in size. It can be as small as a microchip and large for industrial use.

They were signed onto Walmart a month ago and have a good team. They also value the environment over share holders ( which I like ) and are here to actually.make a difference.

They are getting hammered right now, but with the air filtration market to skyrocket, they are poised to soar.

author: DrPechanko
body:
The cult of musk. Enjoy the climb to the bottom. I choose my companies on research. Musk has so many fails that led him bumbling here. 

Corona also created the perfect storm for people to throw there money in a wishing well. 

Do you realize TESLA stock was 198 dollars up until 2019. What changed in a year?! 

300,000 car sales, tunnels under a city, a pig with a chip in its head, 7 failed rocket explosions.....what has changed? 

Im sorry, I really believe that bubble is going to burst. I don’t think Musk is an innovator, and I absolutely don’t believe he is a “genius” or “savant” of any kind. He comes from money....learned to program, invested his own money got richer..

Hold on while I graft a microchip into my brain so I can listen to some music and “maintain my anxiety levels”. Neurolink completed....I am now able to compete with AI cyborgs in the year 3030.

author: leapbitch
body:
Hot take this is what happens when you don't have controls on your critical software patches.

Elon had engineers start a critical software patch for the God damn brakes on a Tuesday morning and they push it out that night.

Potential software bugs aside do you think a car company can legitimately complete full brake testing in an afternoon? From start to finish? And Elon just pushes that shit out into each Tesla on command. Quick aside I feel like a Bill Gates microchip conspiracy theorist except Elon has literally announced his plans for implants and shit.

That's how Boeing did their airplanes that are currently fucked sideways on software errors. Poor dev culture. Literally every industry. Put devs back in leadership of devs but obviously make sure they're savvy too. Don't let a manbaby rule them like the worst parts of Gavin Belson and Dr. Evil and the asshole boss from Office Space. Actual tech companies are marginally better and regular companies fucking slam laptops together for fun.

Tldr I want a tesla but don't want a software update to make my car drive me to elon's house for whatever weird reason he desires that day

author: Ownageforhire
body:
I’m going to have to make another account to do this. I’m just too active on my main accounts to watch x stock slip x amount and not sell and buy back later in the day or etc. Especially this past week or so, markets been going up and down 2-5% during the day for whatever reason. 

I know buy and hold is a good thing. But somehow I just view investing as very hands on. 

What are some stock examples that you have held personally for the last 5+ years that have provided good returns? 

I’m thinking the cloud / microchip companies but it’s very saturated with competition. My other thoughts are to look to China, $baba and newer ev makers and try to capitalize on that countries growth.

author: ehehe
body: Has anyone here ever played anything on Qorvo? Cannot find a single weakness in this company at all, huge tech exposure, already very profitable, great growth prospects, and only a 35 p/e. Anyone have any insight?

author: BumbleFuckDuck
body:
Article from link:

"Zomedica Pharmaceuticals Corp. (NYSE American: ZOM) announced today that it has agreed with its development partner Qorvo Biotechnologies, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Qorvo US, Inc., to develop three new assays -- Cobalamin, cPL (canine Pancreatic Lipase), and Folate -- to target diagnosis of canine gastrointestinal issues. The new assays are in addition to the initial five assays currently under development, including panels for adrenal and thyroid testing, for TRUFORMA™, Zomedica's point-of-care veterinary diagnostic platform. The agreement to pursue development of the new assays has triggered the final $2 million milestone payment under Zomedica’s Development and Supply Agreement with Qorvo.

“Our intent for TRUFORMA™ always has been to have it serve as a broad diagnostic point-of-care tool for dogs and cats and to continue to expand the diagnostic offerings available on the platform," said Robert Cohen, Interim Chief Executive Officer of Zomedica. "We believe that the combination of the Cobalamin, cPL and Folate assays will enable veterinarians to use TRUFORMA to conduct a thorough testing panel to diagnose dogs in gastrointestinal distress."

If successfully developed, the Cobalamin, cPL, and Folate assays will represent what the Company believes is the first non-infectious gastrointestinal panel optimized for use in canines fully available at the point-of-care to facilitate rapid diagnosis of gastrointestinal disorders. Evaluation of the health of different components of the gastrointestinal system is necessary to identify the cause of clinical symptoms. This panel is intended to assay the function of the pancreas, proximal small intestine, and distal small intestine. The Company believes that the ability to conduct testing at the point-of-care will facilitate real-time clinical decision-making, reduce in-patient clinic stay, promote earlier detection and treatment, and increase pet owner satisfaction.

According to a DVM360 study*, ASPCA Pet Insurance, Embrace, Nationwide, Pets Best and Trupanion agree that “GI condition” is the most common insurance claim for dogs. Signs of digestive system disease can include excessive drooling, diarrhea, constipation, vomiting or regurgitation, loss of appetite, bleeding, abdominal pain and bloating, straining to defecate, shock, and dehydration. The TRUFORMA diagnostic device, which is smaller than a desktop printer, is anticipated to provide highly sensitive, species-specific assays using Qorvo’s proprietary, non-optical Bulk Acoustic Wave ("BAW") sensor technology. The BAW sensor is a proven semiconductor technology used in telecommunications and aerospace markets. The Company believes that BAW technology has the potential to improve veterinary diagnostics by delivering reference laboratory accuracy and test performance to the veterinary clinic at the point-of-care."

I bolded the important parts. This is a long hold regardless if r/s happens or does not. IMO the r/s ain't happening.

author: futbolito112000
body:
I had NOK at $4 and sold at $5 after earnings. I also sold options on the shares I owned ($5 call). I believe in the company but people have been burned in the past so they are hesitant to invest in it. They are still restructuring and their products cost more than the other players; however, that should change in 6 or 9 months. Their data center seems promising too and I believe Apple is a customer.  To be honest, it's probably dead money for awhile and it's going to be in this $4 to $5 range. I wouldn't be surprised if it dips under $4.  Maybe pick up 250 shares and sell when it goes up a quarter and wait for pullbacks or hold on for the long term in case they get acquired. Other than that, you are better off with Marvell Technologies, Apple, Qrvo, Qualcomm for a 5G play. Even if you get less shares for $1000, the likelihood of the stock moving up is much greater. Also, if they pay dividends (Apple pays divs but not sure of the others), just reinvest the dividends and you will have more shares in the future. I've been burned by a lot of these cheap stocks that they are almost not worth investing in because they just don't move much.  You can consider having a portfolio of 6 of these under $7 stocks but don't put more than $3k. If one of them pans out, great. Not all will be winners.  

You may want to consider Ark Invest ETFs as I have a couple of them (ARKK and ARKF). The returns have been tremendous and Cathy (CEO) invests in disruptive companies. Vanguard funds are good too and I am considering getting one of the cloud ETFs and information technology ETFs when the market pulls back again as valuations are still too high. I may also look at the IPO ETF and getting some Snowflake (SNOW) shares for the long term. Good luck and I agree to not day trade with your IRA and take profits when the stocks/ETFs climb as you can buy them back again. Try to sell option calls if you have 100 shares for some additional passive income.

author: lostitlosingit
body:
I’m not in FIG, but I focus on a geography where a huge % of the investable universe is FIG. The other thing is that the banking system there is an oligopoly, so I don’t run into regional banks, and unfortunately can’t help you there.  I think with wholesale vs retail, especially if you’re dealing with smaller banks, you have to be cognizant that wholesaled can be a much flightier source of capital if there’s a crisis of confidence. I would make sure you understand average deposits/ broker, you don’t want one broker controlling $100s of MM. 

One thing to also focus on is % of revenue that comes from fees - you have some banks in my geography where 60% of the revenues come from account and credit card fees, which is hugely advantageous as you aren’t exposed to rates. Then you’re almost a tolling business, not a bank. Not sure if that helps considering how oligopolistic my universe is, but that’s my $0.02!

author: eli_lilly
body: Depending on who your broker is, you'll want to be cognizant as to the situation that can arise if you hold the option to its expiration. Some brokers will automatically sell it starting around 3pm on the day of expiration. Other brokers will "exercise" it, which means you'd have to pay for the underlying stock at that point.

author: i_accidently_reddit
body:
how in the world is cognizant a competitor of palantir? out of the bunch the only one doing something remotely similar is splunk, and they are way to focussed on web stuff. (that means they are civil, and while that is also a good market, the margins are smaller) That's like saying Toyota is a competitor to Ferrari 

the attraction of pltr is that it sits in a niche between technology that BAE or booz allen cant do, Niche abilities that IBM cant do, and technical expertise that Accenture or Avanade cant deliver.

There is no real competitor, and it is night impossible to build a similar company.

tech talent loves them. they are almost always top of the list for the best of the best engineers, up there with google, jane street, elastic or shopify.
